bestBHT.bht: Personifying the altar, the voice speaks with the concentrated testimony of the prayers of the saints and the cries for vengeance from the souls of the martyrs beneath. Affirming the true and righteous judgments of the Almighty, the martyred saints acknowledge the deservedness of the judgments upon their persecutors. They applaud the judgments for being what were threatened and in alignment with the realities they faced. This response echoes the demands of perfect righteousness and embraces the righteousness of God's judgment.

Henry Alford: Certainly the simplest understanding of these words is, that they involve personification of the altar.
On the altar are the prayers of the saints, offered before God: beneath the altar are the souls of the martyrs crying for vengeance.
When therefore the altar speaks, it is the concentrated testimony of these which speaks by it.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: On it the prayers of saints are presented before God."
Beneath it are the souls of the martyrs crying for vengeance on the foes of God.
Albert Barnes: True and righteous are thy judgments."
These scenes followed closely on the French revolution, and grew out of it as a natural consequence, and would be properly represented as a second 'vial' poured out immediately after the first.

There was a propriety, therefore, that a voice should be heard ascribing righteousness to God for avenging the blood of the saints Revelation 16:5-6, and that another voice should be heard from the 'altar' of the martyrs Revelation 16:7 responding and saying, 'Even so, Lord God Almighty, true and righteous are thy judgments.'
Philip Schaff: Not only is an acknowledgment of the righteousness of God’s judgment given by the ‘waters;’ the martyred saints also respond."
They who have suffered own that the judgments of the Almighty upon those who persecuted them even unto death are true and righteous.
Conformable to the realities of things and to the demands of perfect righteousness.
Archibald T. Robertson: O Lord God, the Almighty (Κυριε ο θεος ο παντοκρατωρ).
Just as in Revelation 15:3 in the Song of Moses and of the Lamb, vocative with the article ο.
"Judgments" (κρισεις) here instead of "ways" (οδο) there, and with the order of the adjectives reversed (αληθινα κα δικαια, true and righteous).
John Gill: Even so, Lord God Almighty, true and righteous are thy judgments.
Applauding the judgments of Christ upon the worshippers of the beast, from the verity of them, being what were threatened, and from the justice of them, being what they deserved.
John Wesley: Yea — Answering the angel of the waters, and affirming of God's judgments in general, what he had said of one particular judgment.
